Description.val:
Littoral Combat Ship (LCS) focused mission packages provide the operational commander with capabilities to perform littoral Mine Countermeasures (MCM) operations, a detect-to-engage capability to counter small boat threats (Surface Warfare (SUW), and a detect-to-engage capability to counter enemy submarines (Anti-Submarine Warfare (ASW)). A Mission Package (MP) is a combination of warfare Mission Modules (MM) with specialized crew, support equipment, and vehicles, including embarked manned helicopters and unmanned aircraft and maritime systems. Mission Modules are packaged in a modular fashion so that they can be quickly swapped in and out pier side on any LCS platform. 

This line item funds the procurement of MCM and SUW MP support containers and equipment that is common across the mission packages (Mission Package Computing Environment (MPCE), Technology Refresh of the Multi-Vehicle Communications System (MVCS), and Training Equipment).   

The Common Mission Modules Equipment (Line Item Number 1600) by itself or support containers by themselves do not comprise a MP and are only deployable as part of a Mission Module (MM). A MM is deployable and capable of meeting its focused mission requirements on an LCS only when it includes the full complement of Common Mission Modules Equipment combined with all the required mission systems.  

Other Related Budgets: BLIs: OPN 1601, OPN 1602, OPN 1603, OPN 4248, OPN 2622, OPN 2624, WPN 4221, WPN 4225, RDT&E 0603596N

[P40A / LM008 - MPCE]: Commercial Off The Shelf (COTS)- Based Common Computing environment will support legacy Mission Package (MP) Command & Control (C2) applications and transition to Modular Open Systems Approach (MOSA) & Navy Open Architecture Computing Environment (OACE). It also provides a common computing environment to support the execution of Mission Package Application Software (MPAS), the shipboard tactical software associated with each mission package that enables execution of its focused mission.  Includes installation and checkout on-board the seaframe.  In order to support the MPCE Sonar Signal Processing of the Escort Mission Module (EMM), the MPCE needs to be augmented to provide additional processing capabilities.  This includes procurement of MPCE Sonar Signal Process equipment racks. These equipment racks will be co-located with the MPCE processing racks.  In addition, Mission Package Portable Control Stations (MPPCS) are required to support pre-deployment checkouts, to support shore-based and vessels of opportunity operations of mission packages and off-board vehicles.

[P40A / LM012 - TRAINING EQUIPMENT]: Procurement of LCS Mission Module training systems to train LCS crews in the safe and effective use of assigned equipment at LCS Training Facilities (LTF) located in San Diego and Mayport.  
    
    LTF includes tactical watch team training using Common Mission Package Trainer (CMPT) integrated with seaframe Combat Management System (CMS) trainers, a replication of LCS mission bays where LCS MM training systems are moved in and out of the Launch and Recovery (L&R) footprint to train all crews in the safe movement of systems, and revalidate key maintenance skills in the confined mission bay environment.  
    
    Integrated Team Training (ITT) uses the CMPT trainer, with two CMPTs delivered to LCS-1 ITT trainer and LCS-2 ITT trainer in San Diego. CMPT#3 for LCS-1 ITT trainer in Mayport installed in FY2018 and commenced operations in FY2018. CMPT#4 procured in FY2018 to support second San Diego LCS-2 trainer for installation in FY2019. CMPT#5 procurement is in FY2019 to support third San Diego LCS-2 trainer for installation in FY2020.  CMPT#6 procurement is in FY2020 to support third Mayport LCS-1 trainer for installation in FY2021.  MCM and SUW integrated team training commenced at San Diego in FY12 and will commence for SUW only in Mayport in FY2018. MCM ITT functions with USV and UUV capability is procured in FY2019 for planned delivery in Mayport by FY2021.  ASW ITT capability procurement is planned for FY2021 for delivery into the ITTs in FY2023. CMPTs qualify individuals in a team environment (Train to Qualify) and are also used to certify watch teams (Train to Certify) during off hull periods at LTF. 
    
Each mission area will be delivering training systems as follows:  
    
MCM: All unmanned vehicles, sensors, and systems in support containers to demonstrate L&R and maintenance tasks. An Integrated Virtual Shipboard Environment (IVSE) (virtual reality) allow sailors to learn and demonstrate crane operator and system remote operations L&R team coordination.  Procurements are aligned to system delivery to the fleet and support formal training that has commenced in San Diego and will commence in Mayport in FY2020. 
    
SUW: A Mk-46 gun in barbette on a multi-function adapter demonstrates GMM critical maintenance and ammunition loading tasks. MSM AEL equipment is used to support VBSS certification and exercise related shipboard evolutions such as "detainee handling." SSMM module components are used to demonstrate onload tasks. Mission Package Training System (MPTS) is a NAWC TSD PORTS Architecture based training system used in training SUW operators and maintaining gun and missile operator proficiency. Procurements are for incremental system delivery and support formal training that will commence in San Diego and Mayport in FY2022.
    
ASW: Integrated Virtual Shipboard Environment (IVSE) demonstrates ASW system Launch and Recovery (L&R) tasks. Procurements support formal training that will commence in San Diego and Mayport in FY2021. 
    
The LCS MM program is also procuring training systems for installation at other shore locations as follows:
    
Mine Warfare Training Center (MWTC) PT Loma, CA: Training for senior ship and MCM watch standers at Pt Loma, CA. Individuals are trained in MCM mission planning, execution, post mission analysis and re-planning (computer classroom) at MWTC. This course commenced formal training at Mine Warfare Training Center in San Diego (single sited) in FY2017. 
    
Center for Surface Combat Systems Detachment Dam Neck, VA: Fire Controlman (FC) and Gunners Mate (GM) training at Dam Neck VA. MK-50 Modular Gun Weapons System (MGWS) Operations and Maintenance difference trainer co-located with the MK-46 Operations and Maintenance trainer. SSMM Operations and Maintenance trainer for technician training at LTF San Diego. Course will teach SSMM Console Operator (SCO) actions, and SSMM Weapons Zone maintenance and loading/unloading tasks.  MK-50 course formal training commenced in FY2015, and SSMM is expected to commence in FY2022. 
    
Fleet ASW Training Center San Diego, CA: Sonar Technician (STG) pipeline training at Pt Loma, CA. Operator training system for AN/SQS-62 operator training using CMPT- like environment.  Course will include an AN/SQS-62 maintenance trainer for maintenance and deploy/retrieve tasks.  Procurements in FY2020 support formal training that will commence in FY2022.

[P40A / COMMON MISSION PACKAGE TRAINER (CMPT)]: CMPT is procured from AAC under SBIR Phase III contract, and when delivered is integrated with ship combat management system (CMS) trainers capable of being connected to the Navy Cooperative Training Environment (NCTE) for participation in Navy and Joint synthetic training events at the LCS Training Facilities in each home port. A total of 6 are  required, with 3 in San Diego and 3 in Mayport. The first CMPT was procured using RDT&EN.  A CMPT consists of a production Mission Package Computing Environment (MPCE) using one of three mission area Mission Package Application Software (MPAS) and integrated with visualization software (common with ship CMS trainer), models and simulations to stimulate tactical MPAS, scenario generator, and instructor control software. Mission area additions (SUW: GUID, and ASW: EMM processing), and IP communications capability for watchstanders are included.

[P40A / CMPT MPTS Tech Refresh/Modernization]: FY18 funding converts CMPT 1 from MPCE baseline 1.8 to 1.9.1 and in FY19 the program converts CMPT 2 from 1.8 to 1.9.1 as well as refresh the display console.  Starting in FY20, the program will modernize CMPT to incorporate the ASW SIM/STIM capability.

[P40A / MISSION BAY TRAINING DEVICES - MCM]: FY19 procurement is for UISS and Knifefish Technical Training Equipment (TTE).

[P40A / LM015 - CONTAINERS (SHIPPING & SUPPORT)]: Each MP variant uses a base Support Container (SC) which is an International Organization for Standardization (ISO)compliant shipping container, and comes in two variants: Type I and Type II. The Type I container is a 20-foot ISO container with nominal dimensions of 20' x 8' x 8'. The Type II container is a 10-foot ISO container with nominal dimensions of 10' x 8' x 8'. In both cases the base SC is constructed of high strength steel or aluminum to reduce the overall weight and features a number of standard configuration items.  Mission systems fit inside standard ten- or twenty-foot ISO SCs, or on ISO compliant flat racks and vehicle cradles. The LCS MP zones inside each seaframe mission bay are configured to accommodate the SCs.

[P40A / MCM SUPPORT CONTAINER]: Unit price for the MCM Containers is an average cost that does not reflect the actual cost of each container.  Individual containers for each of the different MCM mission systems have unique requirements and vary in cost.

[P40A / LM016 - MVCS]: The Multiple Vehicle Communications System (MVCS) provides the Littoral Combat Ship (LCS) Mission Modules with the capability to simultaneously communicate with multiple Unmanned Surface Vehicles (USVs) and surfaced Unmanned Underwater Vehicles (UUVs) by providing a common data link and network communication services.  These services include link establishment, link management, communications fail-safes, Emissions Control (EMCON) handling, data routing and protection, packet shaping, Priority of Service (PoS), and automated communications system configuration.  MVCS establishes a common interface for these services in the form of hardware and message definitions to maximize the usefulness of limited radio equipment onboard the LCS seaframe.

[P40A / Offboard OTH Communications]: The Multi-Vehicle Communications System (MVCS) is a communications management system that provides common line of sight (LOS), over the horizon (OTH), and satellite communications capabilities for simultaneous sensor data transfer and vehicle control of multiple Littoral Combat Ships (LCS) Mission Module Unmanned Surface Vehicles (USV) and Unmanned Underwater Vehicles (UUVs).  MVCS is an open architected communications system that can be adapted to support any radio system.  This funds procurement and delivery of shipboard and small craft radios and to provide OTH capabilities needed by the Mine Countermeasures (MCM) Mission Package.  The Unmanned Aerial Relay (UMAR) extends the existing LOS high bandwidth capability  (12 Mbps) range out to 30 nautical mile (NM) through use of a tethered quad-copter air relay.  The second solution is the High Frequency Ground Wave (HFGW) radio which provides a direct high bandwidth comms link (452 kbps to 2 vehicles) operating out to 30 NM, without relying on a relay platform.

[P40A / LM900 - CONSULTING SERVICES]: Provides program management support, engineering and technical support, studies, analysis and evaluation on mission package systems.

Justification.val:
FY 2020 funding in LM008 (MPCE) is to support the continued technology refresh of the MPCE (AN/SYK-32) and the MPPCS (to include both shipboard and vehicle side radios); and MPCE Sonar Signal Processing racks procured in FY 2020 are to support the ASW Escort Mission Module (EMM) processing requirement on LCS 21 and LCS 22.    

FY 2020 funding in LM012 (Training Equipment) is to support the technology refresh of one Common Mission Package Trainer (CMPT); procure Operator training system for AN/SQS-62 maintenance and deploy/retrieve tasks; procure MCM and ASW training equipment to support the outfitting of the LCS Training Facility (LTF) in San Diego, CA/Mayport, FL to support training of Independence/Freedom variant crews.  

FY 2020 funding in LM016 (MVCS) supports procurement of Cyber Security and Anti-Jam toolkits, required for each Multiple Vehicle Communications System (MVCS) and is being incorporated and fielded as part of MVCS Technology Refresh.  The MVCS provides the Littoral Combat Ship (LCS) Mission Modules with the capability to simultaneously communicate with multiple Unmanned Surface Vehicles (USVs) and surfaced Unmanned Underwater Vehicles (UUVs) by providing a common data link and network communication services.

Name.@footnote: The MPCE Sonar Signal Processing hardware is provided as adjunct HW to the Mission Package Computing Environment (MPCE) and will be fielded to meet in yard need dates for LCS 21 - LCS 28. It requires periodic upgrades to remain effective and to pace threats. To achieve this, will insert maturing ASW technologies and addressing HW obsolescence in incremental upgrades every four years to the production program via the AxB development process.
Technical Training Equipment that is integrated with Ship Combat Management System to conduct stand-alone MP team training and integrated LCS Team training.
Procurement of ECP's, Tech Refresh, and Modernization to keep CMPT and MPTS current with delivered baseline.

Procurement of MCM components located in an LCS mission bay to replicate the afloat environment as required to support individual qualification and team certification associated with routine and corrective system maintenance in a constrained environment, transportation in the mission bay, pre- / post- operation system maintenance; system launch and recovery.

FiscalYear.@footnote: Unit price for the MCM Containers is an average cost that does not reflect the cost of each container.  Individual containers for each of the different MCM mission systems have unique requirements and vary in cost.

Name.@footnote: Increase in FY20 production engineering funding supports the initial procurement of Unmanned Minesweeping (UMS) Module and Remote Minehunting Module (RMH) containers and associated support.
Quantity reflects total amount of Unmanned Aerial Relay (UMAR) ship-sets, High Frequency Ground Wave (HFGW) ship-sets and HFGW vehicle sets.  Unit price is average of all components.
